edu.rit.gpu.example

Class KnapsackBnbGpu

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.Task
      • edu.rit.gpu.example.KnapsackBnbGpu

  • public class KnapsackBnbGpu
extends Task
    Class KnapsackBnbGpu is a GPU parallel program that solves a knapsack problem using a branch-and-bound search. The program can solve knapsack problems with up to 63 items.

    Usage: java pj2 [gpus=NA] edu.rit.gpu.example.KnapsackBnbGpu [-p] "constructor" [NB [NT]]
    NA = Number of GPU accelerators to use
    -p = Print knapsack problem parameters
    constructor = KnapsackProblem constructor expression
    NB = Number of blocks
    NT = Number of threads per block

    The constructor argument gives a constructor expression for a class that implements interface KnapsackProblem. The program obtains the knapsack problem parameters—knapsack capacity, number of items, weight and value of each item—from an instance of this class. For further information about constructor expressions, see class edu.rit.util.Instance.

    The program performs a branch-and-bound search of the space of 2N possible solutions, where N is the number of items. The search tree is partitioned into chunks. Each chunk consists of a particular subset of items among the first level items (where level = min (N/2, 20)), plus all possible subsets of the remaining items. The program executes a GPU kernel on each of NA GPU accelerators in parallel (default: NA = all GPU accelerators on the node). The kernel consists of a one-dimensional grid of one-dimensional blocks, with NB blocks (default: NB = number of multiprocessors on the GPU) and NT threads per block (default: NT = 256). The search tree chunks are apportioned equally among the NA GPUs. Each GPU thread does a branch-and-bound search on one or more search tree chunks and keeps track of the best solution found. After traversing the entire search tree, the program prints the best solution.

    The program prints the knapsack problem and its solution in the following format. If the -p flag is omitted, the p and i lines are omitted.

    • Lines beginning with # are comments.
    • p zeroOne <C> <N> — Defines a zero-one knapsack problem with knapsack capacity C and N items.
    • i <j> <W_j> <V_j> — Defines the item at index j with weight Wj and value Vj.
    • s <W_total> <V_total> — The solution has total weight Wtotal and total value Vtotal.
    • k <j1> <j2> ... — The solution consists of the items at indexes j1, j2, and so on.
